dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY 4s running for her life, her youthful, exotic. beauty strained but not quite marred by the fear that's tensed the muscles in her face, and stiffened the cords in her neck, and fogged her eyes with the shine of tears. She glances back.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDINGS 2
dialogues.text: Across their street-lit facades flit the ominous shadows of her pursuers, huge and distorted. And, along with these shadows, the echoing SOUND of their racing feet.

dialogues.speaker: MARY 3
dialogues.text: Breathless, gasping, she intensifies her effort to outrun them, but it's hopeless. They're stronger than her, quicker than her.

dialogues.speaker: MEN 4
dialogues.text: There are two of them, built strong and tall. Both wear suits and ties. We're not close enough to see their faces but, curiously, chillingly, we can hear their labored breathing and sense not only their determination, but their anger.

dialogues.speaker: MARY 5
dialogues.text: She skids wildly around a corner, almost slips, almost falls.

dialogues.speaker: MEN 6
dialogues.text: Gaining... gaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three young men, all in their early twenties, buddies, come from the bar, laughing, joking with one another, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 CONTINUED: 7. Two of them are engaged in a little fancy footwork -- shuffle-jab-jab-hook. Mary, running full out, but looking back again, over her shoulder, collides head-on with one of them, JOEY, not quite knocking the two of them to the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Hey, hey, hey! You didn't see the stop sign, or what? Shaken, disoriented, still pressed against Joey, his hands on her arms, Mary looks back. Joey and his friends look.

dialogues.speaker: MEN 8
dialogues.text: They run into view from around the corner, then pull up short as they see Mary with the three young men.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP 9
dialogues.text: Joey silently appraises the situation, glances at his pals, then back at the two men. It doesn't take a genius to put two and two together. He sort of hands Mary to one of his friends, like a package for safekeeping. Then, stepping away from them a few feet, he repositions himself and eyeballs the two pursuers.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) So? Something you want here?

dialogues.speaker: MEN 10
dialogues.text: Unmoving, mute.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, come on, come on, you want it, come and get it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're twins. Same size, same hair, same eyes, same restrained, but evident, ferocity.  13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can all feel it, like an iron fist held back, or maybe a claw, and they're hoping like hell that Joey's bravado, alone, will win the night. There's a pause that, with the tension, seems quite a bit stronger than it really is.

dialogues.speaker: MEN 14
dialogues.text: They turn away, walk away, and disappear around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP 15
dialogues.text: A collective sigh of profound relief, quickly disguised -- as best they can -- by some satisfied laughter.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (with a slap on Joey's back) Way to go, champ! And then the other friend, RALPH, raises a megaphone- shaped hand to his mouth and issues a loud series of chicken sounds in the general direction of the departed enemy. Everyone laughs, and even Mary seems to relax a bit and almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR JOEY 16
dialogues.text: He turns to her, really looking at her for the first time. And now STEWY and Ralph do the same. There's a bit of discreet glancing between the three pals, as all of them come to the same and obvious decision: Mary is gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: You okay? She nods, smiles again -- just slightly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you. It was just a few words, but enough to detect an accent; but not a readily identifiable one. What it does, though, is make her even more exotic than she already seems. Joey glances at the empty street corner, then back at Mary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ‘ JOEY @ Close call, huh? Couple of creeps.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Looked like foreigners, if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (mockingly serious) Yeah. You'd never see two guys in this city act like that. Ralph slaps Stewy on the head. Stewy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (to Mary) So... everything's alright now? I mean, you'll be okay if we leave you alone?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (not too convincingly) Yes. Joey and the boys exchange dubious glances. e JOEY You live around here?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm... visiting.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? You're not lost, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. I think I can find my way. Joey nods. A bit of an awkward silence. Then, obviously reluctant to end it, but not sure how to continue:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (to the guys) What d'tyou think? Stewy and Ralph exchange a glance. STEWY ; What d'we think? We think you'd be nuts to leave her out here a e@ all by herself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: svi mUve 3/08 > 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : . (indicating). . ' Those guys could still be See tel, for her, just hiding . ‘Out, right around the corner ' there. ; Cee Joey nods, mulling it over. : What d'you say I give you a xide someplace...put you on a bus or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17. PAVOR MARY . est 17 She hesitates, as if trying to read something in * Joey's eyes. Then she nods. . 7 7

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thank you. : 18 FAVOR JOEY a . 1s aN eames eh ‘JOEY Well, it's settled then. My e : - ear's right over there. * (then, to Stewy: and Ralph) You guy’s gonna be okay? = tw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZI think we can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: (nods; then) Yeah. Take it easy. (ConTINvED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (to Mary) - It was a real pleasure... running into you. Mary nods, smiles shyly. Stewy taps Joey's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: See you in the morning. Joey nods. Stewy and Ralph take off across the street after a final, private grin toward Joey and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, MARY 19
dialogues.text: A moment of silence between them. :

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Well, you all set? She nods. He gestures. They head toward his car, an early 70's Chevy convertible with the top down. It's in mint condition. As they approach it:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Know anything about cars? She shakes her head; again the shy grin.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Too bad. Been working on it for two years. (grins) It'll just about fly. Mary looks at the car with new interest as Joey opens the passenger door for her, then moves around to get in behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: So...is this your first time in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE MAIN TITLES as the Chevy cruises through light traffic. We don't hear Joey's conversation but he looks like a tour-guide. He's proud of his city and his car. Mary's interest is keen. cuUT TO:  ini gtd mt 22 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Revs Nov. 5/84 — “2,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. STREET CORNER - WIGHT Bee 21 Joey pulls the Chevy to the curb. ‘He's stopped * in front of a bus stop. Mary looks at it. It's 7 @ well-lighted area, but a lonely one. There's a lengthy pause, as if both are undecided about what they should do next. Then, with some reluctance, she opens the car door and steps out, closing it behind her. se leet . Another pause. She looks back at Joey. He nods, smiles just slightly, then sort of salutes her with a little wave. Mary returns the gesture - almost as if imitating it. eee) Joey shifts into gear, spins the wheel, swings a U-turn. WIDER = SCENE dose 22 Mary approaches the bench and sits neatly. The Chevy cruises slowly away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches the taillights begin to fade away.  en 24 25 26 27 8.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY 24
dialogues.text: Driving away, he keeps one eye on her small image in the rearview mirror. She looks vulnerable as hell. He steps on the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY 25
dialogues.text: For the first time we see a sign of hope in her expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just a few cars parked beside it. Joey's 1s one of then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only other customers sit at the counter. Joey and - Mary are opposite one another in a booth, the WAITRESS standing beside them, waiting with her pencil and order pad.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: What're you gonna have? Mary doesn't respond, seeming uncertain, or maybe even confused.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Waitress) I'll have a bowl of chili; double side of oysterettes.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Somethin' to drink?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: And you, dear?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The same?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: It's up to you, sweetheart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mary seems at a loss again. Joey takes charge.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Just make it for two; huh? Nice and easy.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: (leaving) Thanks, hon. There's a silence between them. Joey's not only charmed by her, he's puzzled. But now, nodding in agreement to his own statement:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I'm thinking. I'm thinking you're not just from another part of the country... but from a whole different country, (taps his ear) I'm hearing an accent. Mary lowers her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Give the man a prize. He repositions himself in his seat, really starting to enjoy this.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Okay... let's see how Sherlock Holmes would do this... A pause for serious concentration. Then, using his fingers for emphasis, as he counts off his major deductions:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) One: you're on the run. Two: like Ralph said, the guys that were after you looked like foreigners. Three: you don't talk a lot, maybe because you're trying not to give yourself away. Which means... four: that you've got something to hide. Which leads me to... five: that wherever you're from, you're not supposed to be here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED, (2)
dialogues.text: A silence. He watches her, searching her expression for clues.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) What d'you say? Am I getting warm? (he grins) Maybe even a little "red" around the cheeks? Joey glances around, surreptitiously. Then, leaning forward and lowering his voice:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do I see an Iron Curtain in your not-so-distant past? Mary merely stares at hin, looking like she doesn't know whether to laugh or cry. Joey shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (contdnuing) Hey, forget it, it's none of my business, right? He sits back, picks up his spoon, plays with it. Mary watches him curiously. Then, terrifically conversational:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) So, tell me, you married? Got a@ boyfriend? Mary shakes her head "no."

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Me either. I mean, I'm not merried either. Don't even have a girlfriend. Can't afford one. He politely waits for her to pick up the conversation. When she doesn't:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Any sisters? Brothers? Mary shakes her head again. It's starting to sound like an interview, which means it's starting to sound like a first date. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've got one sister, kid sister, Goes to college in Wisconsin. (humbly but proudly) That's why I'm broke all the time. I help her out, you know? (pause; then) ’ How about your folks? Still living?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, I haven't any parents.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (nods sympathetically) Well, you see that? We've got a couple of things in common. ne are gone, too. Died when I was sixteen. Annie was only twelve, poor little kid. He seems to momentarily drift off in a melancholy way. Mary appears to be studying him. The Waitress returns. |

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Here you go, kids: two bowls of chili, extra oysterettes, two coffees. Cream and sugar on the table. After the momentary racket of plates and cups hitting the formica, the Waitress leaves and the silence returns. Then --

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Go on, dig in, you look hungry. Mary stares at the chili, once again seeming uncertain. Joey begins preparing his own, practically drowning it in oysterettes. Watching him, Mary does it the same way. Joey grins.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) No chili in the U.S.S.R., huh? She doesn't respond. He smiles, then laughs a little -- quite proud of his insightful detection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them walk out.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Nice place, huh? We call that a@ "greasy spoon."

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Greasy...?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Spoon. First time, right? I mean, having chili.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Well, what'd you think?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It was... very good.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (smiles) You don't sound too sure.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It was different.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I bet. Wasn't even on : pumpernickel. He opens the car door for her and she slides in. Then, just before Joey slides in after her, he catches a glimpse of a car parked across the street.

dialogues.speaker: CAR 29
dialogues.text: It's a big new Mercedes four-door, bullet gray, hulking and formidable in the darlmess.

dialogues.speaker: PAVOR JOEY 30
dialogues.text: He slides in behind the wheel of the Chevy as if he never saw the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've got to ask you something: Those guys -- did they have wheels? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: A car, Sensing the very subtle edge in his voice, she starts to look around.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) : Don't turn around. Rigid, in fear again, she sits motionless, facing front. Joey starts the engine, acting casual as all get-out.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They have a gray car.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (nods) Yeah, and expensive taste. - He pauses a moment to think. She watches him.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Tell me something else: are they packing?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Guns. Are they carrying guns? I mean, how serious are these guys? Mary looks away. A silence. Then, making a decision to trust him:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They're very serious... and very dangerous. Joey nods, his worst suspicions confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Okay. One more thing: how well do they know this city?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They've only been here for two days... like me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (mutters under his breath) Be thankful for little favors. Now, with determination he shifts the car into first gear. He glances at her and smiles briefly, as if to reassure both of them.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hang on. He revs the engine, pops the clutch. The tires screech and spin and smoke. The Chevy roars out of the diner's parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: The headlights flash on, the engine fires, and with a powerful lurch, the big car takes off after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not somuch a chase as it is a game of follow-the- leader... through an obstacle course. Joey's a native and he knows the city inside out and backwards. He also knows that the Mercedes is twice as quick as his old Chevy, so the only hope he's got is to run and hide. Specific locations will be selected which will ultimately allow Joey -- with his superior knowledge of the turf -- to escape the pursuers, but not before he and Mary come perilously close, more than once, to disaster. It's a hair-raising sequence that establishes one thing with extreme clarity: the two men who are after Mary -- for whatever reason -- are determined to succeed; maybe even if it means their own destruction. Regardless of 31 32 how many times Joey manages to elude them, they reappear; the gray Mercedes rising out of the ashes like some terrible beast: pushing on, coming back, unstoppable. Through the tinted windows of the car their faces are obscured, but not their savage tenacity. In the end Joey and Mary sit in the parked Chevy in some dark and unseen crevice and, holding their breath, watch the Mercedes roar past and fade into the night -- this time, at least, not to return. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joey turns to her, and she to him. It's too soon to feel the exhilaration of having somehow, miraculously, won this battle. Knowing it or not, wilful or not, he has saved her life two times this-evening. She stares at him curiously. For some inexplicable reason, she doesn't understand why he's acted the way he has. But, as for Joey -- up to this point -- he's merely acted out of instinct. Joey breaks the silence for the first time since he and Mary left the restaurant. It's a masterpiece of quiet understatement:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I think we better have a talk. Brief pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them are trudging toward the top floor, the fifth floor. Right now they're between the third and fourth floor landings. The stairway 1s poorly lit and the building looks like it's probably older than the hills.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I've been climbing these stairs for eight years. When I first moved in, the super says to me: Kid, you're going to have legs like iron pipe. Then last month this new guy moves in. I hear the super tell him: Kid, it's fantastic for the cardio- vascular system. Funny how times change, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're nearing the top.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) So now I got legs that'll outrun The Six Million Dollar Man; a heart like a rocket pump; and a pair of lungs that could blow up a blimp. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY (cont'd) But you know what? I'd give it all up for an extra hundred bucks a week and an apartment in a building with an elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. and Joey steps in, standing aside for Mary to enter -- which she does, with great curiosity. Joey comes in, flips on a light, closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY
dialogues.text: She merely stands there, trying to take as much of it in as she can. He watches her in silence.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: May not be much, but it's home to me. As Mary continues to survey the Anterior, Joey walks into the kitchen. The apartment is three rooms; living room/bedroom, kitchen, and bath. The furniture is in okay condition, even though it hasn't been changed since the 50's. The apartment looks pretty clean, actually homey in a way. There are a few posters on the walls, carefully picked. One's a nice picture of Marilyn Monroe -- just her sad smiling face. Another one's a Photo of some wild horses galloping through a stream. In a corner 1s a baseball bat, glove and ball; and beside that, a bowling ball in its bag. Mary pauses in front of a couple of framed photographs.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing; at the fridge) My folks, back in '74, And that's Annie. Beautiful, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: How about a beer? I know they've got beer where you come from. 7 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joey pulls two cans from the fridge, pops the tabs, and walks back into the main room, handing her one.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) How d'you say it? Skol? Nyet? She doesn't respond. He gives up, taps their cans together.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY -
dialogues.text: (continuing) Cheers. He takes a slug, slumps down onto the couch, seeming weary for the first time. She watches him, once again following his lead, sits down on a chair opposite.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SHOT 37
dialogues.text: They silently appraise one another.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) How about we start with names. But let's keep it simple, okay? First names only. (pause; pointing to himself) Me Joey. (points to her) You...?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Mary. Joey stares at her, not believing it for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Mary? That's a Russian name now? Like in Jesus and Mary? Mary smiles shyly. Joey takes another sip of his beer, never taking his eyes off her.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You don't have the slightest idea of what I'm talking about, do you? ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A silence. He leans forward, as if to see her more closely.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Look, I don't want to poke my nose in where it doesn't belong. But the way I see 1t, you've got a problem. And because we sort of... got together... I feel a little responsible, and I figure I ought to try and do | something to help you out. ' Mary continues to listen intently, but to say nothing. On occasion -- usually after he does -- she takes a sip of her beer.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) But you've got to give a little, you know? You've got to tell me 7 what's going on. Just so I'm not groping around in the dark, running into walls and things, stubbing my toes. He's remarkably earnest, and Mary would have to be from another planet not to sense at least some of that. She stands, walks across the room to one of the windows facing the street. She pulls the curtain aside and looks out. He watches her, his eyes squinting a bit, his brow furrowed, as his brain continues to be severely taxed by her mystery. She turns back to face him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Those men...

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They want to capture me. (pause; then) Or kill me.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (the reality is hard to accept) Kill you? Just because you Jumped the wall? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: han ate Pea cries 38 I don't understand. | Are you” _ Some kind of scientist or. @omething? ...- : oS | 44 ” WARY They have orders, _ “2 gory Orders tokiliz . & somber pause. a :

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They have orders to bring me back... alive or dead. This is , 80 they can show the others —- prove to the others — that there's no hope in escape. _ FAVOR JOEY ; There was no denying the tragic sincerity of her words, or the manner in which she spoke them. Joey begins to ‘ boil. He puts his can of beer down, stands up, walks across the room, stops, stares at a wall — almost r, his burning a hole in it with his seething ange: outrage. Then, turning back to face her: : JOEY ; (quietly, but with chilling determination) You've got my word, right here . @nd now, that even if I'm going ‘to die trying, there's no way those bums are going to get what they came for. his is a free country, and I'ma free man — born and raised. And so long you want to stay here, with me, you're free. . : (pause; then) ; Okay?. Rev: Nov. 5/84_

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY
dialogues.text: There are tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't understand why you would be willing to do this.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR JOEY
dialogues.text: Her question wasn't unexpected. His eyes appear to twinkle. He's so proud of his thoughts, he can hardly be any prouder to voice them.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: That's because where you've come from, freedom's not a tune you whistle. But believe me when I tell you: once you learn that tune... nobody, not anybody... can take it away from you. A beat, and then he extends his hand. She's hesitant to respond, but then she does. He takes her hand in his and shakes it. A pause. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cars move on the street, and only a few lights glow from behind curtained windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey's asleep on the couch beneath a blanket. The covers have been pulled back on the bed, but Mary's not in it. Instead, she stands, still dressed, by the window, staring out.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WINDOW
dialogues.text: to a starry sky and a delicate, crescent moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stillness surrounds her like a veil of loneliness. She turns to look at Joey. 20. 39 4o 4d 42 43 44

dialogues.speaker: JOEY 45
dialogues.text: He sleeps undisturbed, a pure and untroubled soul. ANGLE - MARY Soe 46 She quietly crosses toward a chair. Several lamps are on in the room. As she passes them, she glances toward each one, and each one, in turn, goes out.

dialogues.speaker: MARY 47
dialogues.text: She sits down in front of the small black and white television, curling her legs under her. She stares at the set for a second or two. It switches on, by itself. She settles back to watch an old western. She doesn't bother to turn up the volume. She watches in silenee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city begins to wake and stretch. EXT. JOEY'S BUILDING — DAWN 4g Still quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wakes to an unexpected aroma, blinking his eyes, sniffing.

dialogues.speaker: PAVOR MARY 51
dialogues.text: She sits where we last saw her, on the chair in front of the mute television. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: "Morning.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: "Morning.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: What's that I smell?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Something for us to eat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joey pushes the blanket aside and rises from the couch in his boxer shorts and T-shirt. He walks into the kitchen, Mary trailing behind him, appearing a little anxious.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SHOT
dialogues.text: Joey follows his nose to the stove. There's a pot of coffee brewing, and a pot on the stove, covered, He glances at her, quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I found things in there and there. She points to a cupboard and the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Was that alright? Joey looks back at the covered pot, then reaches out -- a bit tenuously -- and raises the lid.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Chili? She nods, evidently pleased that he at least recognized

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) For breakfast? Her hopeful expression begins to fall.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) No, no, I love chili! It's my favorite thing in the world. I just never thought of having it first thing in the morning. He grabs a spoon, spoons up a mouthful, almost inhales it. Mary watches intently. He savors it, chews, Swallows, It's truly good, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's fantastic! You could win a contest. She nods, very pleased. He nods, happy to make her happy. He takes another spoonful, makes the - appropriate delighted faces.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You sure you didn't defect from Mexico? Mary stares at him, confused. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You've got a lot to learn, Comrade Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes from the bathroom, dressed in his mechanic's uniform. Mary's watching television again, still without sound, now a particularly silly game show. Joey leans down and turns up the volume.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Better, huh? She nods, but we're left with the distinct and lingering impression that she's always been hearing the sound.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've got to go to work. I want you to stay here, okay? We've got the weekend coming up and we'll have time to try and work things out. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Promise me... no tours of the neighborhood, no boat rides, no shopping. Okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay. A beat. He glances at the television.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: We've got lots of channels, you know. You can learn all kinds of stuff, She nods, smiles. He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I think I figured out why they want you back so bad. You've got a face that could launch a thousand missiles. She may or may not have understood him. He smiles at . her, clearly reluctant to leave. But then, knowing he has to, he reaches out, touches her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) See you at four-thirty. Then he turns, crosses the room, and walks out without looking back.

dialogues.speaker: MARY 56
dialogues.text: She stares after him, after he's gone, warmed by his brief touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey bounds lightly down the stairs, whistling a tune, and maybe even rides a banister or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey rounds the landing and starts down the final flight.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR 59
dialogues.text: It opens with a glare of sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: He looks.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: The twins from last night fill the frame with their massive bulk. (From this point on, for descriptive purpose, they'll be referred to as the Nazis.)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Momentarily immobilized.

dialogues.speaker: NAZIS
dialogues.text: They've seen him.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Barely taking the time to mutter an indecipherable curse under his breath, he spins around and takes off back up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: NAZIS
dialogues.text: Following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counting his blessings for eight years of developing his iron pipe legs, rocket pump heart, and blimp inflating lungs, Joey almost flies up the stairs. It's as if he's Jet-propelled. — The Nazis Jog in unison, one step at a time -- clearly not as quick as Joey, but just as clearly unphased by the effort. There's something almost robot-like in their perfectly even pacing. And in their expressions, the same frigid coldness we saw last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stands in front of the open medicine cabinet, an opened bottle of cologne in one hand, an open tube of toothpaste in the other, tentatively sniffing them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But now, sensing danger, she looks toward the living room, 7

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (muffled; distant) Mary?! Get out! Run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey sails around the fourth floor landing and charges up the final flight. :

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Mary! Mary!

dialogues.speaker: NAZIS 69
dialogues.text: Machine-like, frighteningly precise, their legs piston up and down on the wooden stairs of the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey, sweating, gasping, hurls his body onto the landing and spins around the corner toward his apartment door.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR 71
dialogues.text: It opens, and Mary's there. Joey doesn't slow down, just barrels through, taking her with him, slamming the door behind then,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey lurches back around, slams the deadbolt.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Why're you still here?! Didn't you hear me?! I told you to get out! Not waiting for her response, he grabs her hand, hauls her across the room. In the b.g., we HEAR the tromp- tromp-tromp of the Nazis’ feet.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, MARY
dialogues.text: He flings open one of the windows, leaps out onto the fire escape, then reaches back to haul her onto it with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nazis take the final few steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand in hand, Joey in the lead, they clatter noisily down the iron stairways. The fire escape shudders against their weigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bursts open, as if from the blow of a sledge- hammer. The Nazis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey and Mary are on the second flight from the street. Mary glances up.

dialogues.speaker: NAZIS
dialogues.text: They step out onto the fire escape from Joey's window. One of them reaches under his jacket and withdraws a gun.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY
dialogues.text: (a frightened Joey! He spins, looks up. it.

dialogues.speaker: NT
dialogues.text: enter.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: shout)

dialogues.speaker: NAZIS 80
dialogues.text: ‘The one with the gun fires. It's a louder explosion and a brighter flash than we're used to seeing.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY AND MARY 81
dialogues.text: Whatever was shot from the gun now strikes the iron stairway Just a few feet above them, blowing a flaming hole in it, six feet around. The portion of the stairs Joey and Mary are on begins to buckle and groan.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Hang ont!!!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 82
dialogues.text: With both of them clinging to the railing, they watch in horror as bolts snap from the ancient concrete side of the building and, slowly, their portion of the stairs begins to sag, and then sink, and then fall toward the street. Thankfully, though, none of this happens in a - rush. Instead, bending under its own weight, the staircase politely arcs closer and closer to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: NAZIS 83
dialogues.text: The shooter shoots again.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY AND MARY 84
dialogues.text: They Jump the last few feet to the alley floor, and not @ second too soon. Behind them, the last existing portion of the lower stairway explodes like the Fourth of July.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (shouting to Mary) Are those guys crazy?! I asked you 1f they had guns, not canons! (then, grabbing her hand) Come on! Run! They run toward the street.  85 86° 87 89 es

dialogues.speaker: NAZI WITH GUN . 85
dialogues.text: For the first time we see the weapon in close detail, and curiously it doesn't look ail that different than a streamlined 9mm semi-automatic. What it shoots, though, is clearly another story. And now the Nazi shoots for the third time. tee

dialogues.speaker: JOEY. AND MARY
dialogues.text: Racing toward the street, the impact of the explosion ten yards ahead of them kmocks them to the ground. What went sky-high was Joey's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sprawled on the pavement, he whirls around to look back up toward the top of the fire escape.

dialogues.speaker: NAZIS 88
dialogues.text: A beat, and then they disappear back into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: PAVOR JOEY 89
dialogues.text: He doesn't understand. His surging adrenalin mixes with his anger and definace and massive confusion. He leaps to his feet, stares in pain at his destroyed car, then turns back to where the Nazis were.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (Ceontinuing; shouting crazily) Where're you going?! Why don't you try and finish what you started! (then, to Mary, and still shouting) I don't understand this! I don't understand any of this! What the hell is going on here?! A brief, crushing silence. cur To:  : . a : Kev. .Dec. 14/84

A telephone is ringing but no one is acknowledging it. Stewy slides out from under a car, muttering a curse. Then, : ; STEWY . aos (louder) What's the matter? Everybody gone deaf around here all of a sudden. He crosses to the phone, wiping his oily hands on an oily cloth. He lifts the receiver.

What happened to your . car? {looks at his. watch) Yeah, yeah, alright, okay, OG ; : we'll pick you up. Lunchtime. : Where? What're you doing there? What? Hiding from who? Joey? e Joey? Mary's standing beside one of the tables, quietly intent as she very carefully arranges the red balls on a snooker table into a particular - if unpredictable - pattern. To one side of the table are three white balls.

dialogues.text: He's speaking to Stewy over a pay phone, his voice’ tow, his manner quietly urgent.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (over phone) Never mind what happened to my car. I just need yours, okay? Look no more questions, alright? (looks at his watch) Okay. Noon. Right. He replaces the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: 7 I want to explain...everything. . . . JOEY ; _ f w Good idea. : eee samedaeeaeaeL tetetel dealt 7 : i: 7 ms a She looks back down at the arrangement of balls. ha

dialogues.speaker: MARY .
dialogues.text: More than that. Much more. She looks back at hin, steadily;into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm not from anywhere around here. Not five thousand miles. Not a hundred thousand miles. Not a hundred million miles. He returns her stare, not even close to ready to believing her; but for a number of reasons -- some seen, some felt -- not ready to object, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns her look to the snooker table. She places | the first white ball near the corner of the table | closest to them. |

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earth. He watches her, oblivious to the fact that he's begun to hold his breath. She places the second white ball Just an inch or two away from the first.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Your sun,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too much, too crazy -- but he continues to watch her, almost as if under a spell. |

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY 97
dialogues.text: She walks the length of the snooker table, and there, on the opposite side from where Joey stands, she places the third white ball. She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) My planet. My home.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR JOEY 98
dialogues.text: He stares at the table. His eyes slowly sweep from one end to the other -- the distance suddenly appearing as vast as the universe. He looks back at Mary. Silence. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 FADE IN: |. a fatale ; : 99°. INT. woon HALL - pay ee tat tale] , cee Nothing has changed. The siience costanues. it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a long time, the people of . Planet lived in peace...so0 long” that we forgot war, forgot what it meant to have an enemy. But now we do. And because we kn no other way, we've become their slaves.” ... 2 : te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -‘She searches his eyes for ‘understanding. Then, ag 4 . fy . . "MARY , . : (continuing) : I escaped. I travelled for a long time; I don't know how long. But when I found this planet, your . earth, I thought I would be safe. ; (pause; she looks away, defeated) I was wrong. : Another brief silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) They didn't kill us this morning, because they want me alive. They want me as an example. But I know this enemy; I know the . planet they come from; I know what they've done; and I know that they will kill me, if I give them no other choice.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Today was a warning... to you. Next time, unless I surrender to them, they'll kill both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although Mary did all the talking, Joey feels exhausted. He slumps back against the table behind him. She watches him. Then, shaking his head, groping for words, feeling somehow embarrassed and not knowing why:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's difficult to accept, I know that. 5

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (chokes on a laugh) Difficult?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But not impossible, I hope. But it is almost hopeless. He turns away, stares at a wall, stares at the other tables, then looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Can you do something? I mean, ean you... can you... (waves his hands vaguely) +..- do a trick or something? Work a miracle? Fly around the room. Turn invisible? His desperation 1s steadily increasing.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I mean, you've got to... you can't just expect... (then, almost anguished) Give me some proof!  35.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY 103
dialogues.text: A silence. Understanding his need, she slowly turns and begins to look around the billiard’ room. He watches her. Then, spotting a dozen balls scattered on one of the tables, she slowly approaches it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, BALLS, JOEY
dialogues.text: She stares down at the numbered balls. Joey watches, having no idea of what to expect. For a moment, nothing. But now one of the balls begins to roll, just slowly, toward one of the pockets. ~ Joey's mouth drops open a bit. A tiny bead of perspira- tion appears on Mary's forehead. The rolling ball, still traveling slowly, approaches the pocket, crosses the lip, drops in. Joey moves from his position, moving like a man under water, his eyes never leaving the pool table, as he comes closer to it. Another ball has started to roll, this one just a little faster; and this one, too, drops into a pocket. Joey stares at her. More perspiration has appeared on her face, but she seems impossibly calm. Then, a SOUND. Joey looks back down. Two balis now, and then three, begin to roll toward different pockets. And then, even before all of them have sunk, others start rolling. Joey's eyes dance around the table, watching first this ball, then that one, then another, then still another, until -- finally -- all are in motion, and all are gone, and the table is bare.

dialogues.speaker: MARY 105
dialogues.text: She turns to him, her face shimmering with perspiration.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR JOEY 106
dialogues.text: He turns to her... almost, but not quite entirely, ready to believe. She senses his hesitation, his turmoil, his innocence battling with whatever has jaded him, has jaded nearly all of us. And she knows that what she's said and what she's done still isn't enough.

Just drive, okay? = : 7 Drive where? We've got to punch back in in forty-five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (brittle) Please, Stewy, just do me a favor and drive, will you? — Stewy glances over his shoulder at both Joey and Mary, and then at Ralph beside him. Ralph encourages. him with a nod.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: Sure. Whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewy's car pulls forward and begins to wind its way out of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an area within the city, but remote in its own way. Stewy's car appears, slows and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewy cuts the engine and for a moment the four of them merely sit there in silence, each of them staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (continuing; still without turning) So? Are you going to let us in on this or not? Joey's wrestling with the answer, confused, almost painfully confused. Ralph turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Look, since when did any of us start going it alone? All for one and one for all, right? Isn't that how it's always been?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, but this time... He trails off into uncertainty. Stewy turns around. He looks at Mary, then at Joey. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: Just spit it out, will you? \ You're in trouble. Maybe the ' lady's in trouble. “But how bad can it be, huh? I mean, you just met her yesterday, so she can't be pregnant, right? He looks from Joey to Mary, hoping to crack a smile. But no luck. He glances at Ralph. Ralph shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Mary) Pardon me, miss... (then, to Joey) You know what your problem is? It's the same as it's always been: you don't know what you want out of life. So when something good happens to you -- like maybe meeting this nice young lady, here -- you get all - erazy and confused. He pauses again, to see if he's getting through. By ' Joey's expression, it seems doubtful. :

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Remember back a couple of weeks before I got married? Remember that? Remember how I went a little nuts? All of a sudden I didn't know what I...

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (cuts him off) Mary's from another planet. What follows 1s a silence like no other we've heard thus far. So complete, it's like a vacuum. But then --

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: What did you say.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (disturbingly calm) She's from another planet. From another... galaxy. (pause; then) She's not a human being. Another brief, but excruciating, silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: (a simple, straight- forward question) Are you crazy? I mean, have you completely freaked out? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Look, forget it, okay? Just let me borrow the car for a couple of days, that's all I need right now.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: That's all you need? Are you kidding me? That's all you need? You need a straight- acket, that's what you et The two of you!

dialogues.speaker: JOEY -
dialogues.text: Are you going to loan me the ear or not?

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: For what?! So you can drive her home?! Giving up, Joey opens the rear door, climbs out -- pulling Mary after him -- then slams it shut.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I'll see you around, Still with Mary in tow, he trudges away.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (calling) Hey, wait a second! Just wait @ second!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 114
dialogues.text: Joey stops, turns back. Stewy climbs from the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: Well, I want to ask you something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e No, I haven't been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: Well, let me ask you this, then... But then he pauses, turns to Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (continuing; awed by himself) Why am I even standing here trying to talk to this man?

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Beats me. A pause. Stewy, obviously a glutton for punishment, turns back to Joey.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: Okay. Answer me this: if this lady here is from another planet, from another... galaxy... (pause; then) C . How come she happens to look exactly like we do? A silence. Joey looks at Mary, then back at Stewy. He seems stumped. Stewy waits, now folding his arms across his chest, quite pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY '
dialogues.text: Well, let me ask you something. STEWY. Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: You believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Do you believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: What kind of a question is that? Of course I believe in God. You know I believe in God. How many | times have we been to church | e together? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Do you believe we were created in God's image? Stewy smells a trap but can't quite figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: STEWY
dialogues.text: (haltingly) Yeah. So?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: So how many images do you think He has? Zapped. Joey nods to both Stewy and Ralph, takes Mary's hand, starts to march away. But Mary resists.. She stops to look back at Joey's friends.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Come on, we're wasting our time with these lugs.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY 115
dialogues.text: She seems to be struggling with a decision. But now she makes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glimmer of intensity flickers across her expressian.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY 117
dialogues.text: He watches her, then turns toward Stewy and Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR STEWY AND RALPH 118
dialogues.text: Stewy, suddenly sensing something, looks up. Ralph looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's snowing on them. Just on them. Nowhere else. A lovely, soft and silent snow.  220 221 2122

dialogues.speaker: REV. DEC. 17/84
dialogues.text: CLOSE - JOEY © : His mouth drops open,

dialogues.text: A tiny amtle. , o

dialogues.text: It continues to snow, gently,-on Stewy and Ralph. Mary reaches out and takes Joey's hand, and now it's she, instead of he, who leads them away. Joey continues to stare back over his shoulder. Stewy and Ralph seem to have turned to stone as they stare up in breathless wonder at the falling snow. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~— Joey and Mary are in the place, Joey engaged in 7 conversation with thé chinese waiter, Mary watching, @ fascinated by the new language. The waiter Speaks no En Joey speaks no Chinese. The problem is that Joey is attempting to order a particular dish,, only he can't remember what it's called. All he can do is try to describe it - in increasingly more elaborate detail. But since the waiter doesn't understand English, the -situation seems hopeless. Joey's frustration intensifies. He begins using his hands in his attempts to communicate visually. It's beginning to look like a game of charades. The waiter continues to rattle off the names of every single chinese dish he can think of. But not one of them rings Joey's bell. But now, after listening carefully, Mary has caught on to the basics of the Chinese vocabulary. She turns to ' Joey and speaks for the first time in this scene. What | she says, very clearly and very precisely, is the name the mystery dish. “The waiter looks at her. Joey looks at her. Theré's a brief, stunning silence, and then both men practically explode in enthusiastic affirmation. With immense relief the waiter walks back to the kitchen to Place the order. Joey stares at Mary, once again awed by her.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I don't get it. How did you ' do that? I couldn't think of it. He didn't know what I was talking about. But you figured it out. ;

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: ' You were thinking about it, ! Joey. A pause. In a way he understands what she means, but he's : not quite ready to accept it. He shakes it off, wants | to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Chopsticks. | He picks his up. She looks at hers, picks them up | ' similarly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to think of them | like an old fork, you know? Like all the teeth fell_out. Watch. He demonstartes, using his chopsticks to pick up an imaginary bite of food and place it into his‘mouth. A dubious hesitation, and now Mary does the same. He watches her carefully, silently encouraging her. Then,

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Crazy, huh? :

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I like it. He grins, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Figures. Another silence. Then,

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with you? She stares at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: . JOEY
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you brought a map with you so you could show me where you live... where you came from. She shakes her head. Another pause,’ and now a thought . begins brewing in Joey's head.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Wait a second... Wait a second... Another pause, and now he suddenly jumps up, turns toward the kitchen, shouts to the waiter:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Can you make that ‘to go'?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. PLANETARIUM - DAY — LONG SHOT - JOEY AND MARY -- 123 They walk side by side, Joey setting e@ fast pace, talking to Mary non-stop, gesturing. se & EXT. OBSERVATORY — DAY : 124 They almost jog up the wide stone stairs and enter the ~ bullding. ; CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall echoes with their footsteps. Joey knows where he's going. He leads her down a hall, up some stairs , and finally into one room in particular. He quietly closes the door behind them. : "INT. PLANETARIUM ROOM — DAY 126 The large, domed-ceilinged room is empty and dim. In the center, the hulking form of the projector. He takes . her hand and leads her to the intricate piece of equipment. The two of them stare down at the vast panel | of switches and dials. cur 10;

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR JOEY
dialogues.text: He's at a loss to know what to do, which switch to pull. Knowing he's got to start somewhere, he reaches out —- tentatively -- toward one likely-looking switch.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY
dialogues.text: She stops his hand, shakes her head. He stares at her. She looks down at the panel, obviously trying to familiarize herself with it, to understand it. And now, slowly, she goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey watches in awe as Mary manipulates the panel, dims the lights in the room, causes a pattern of stars to appear on the black ceiling. She changes the pattern 43. 127 128 129 once, then again, then again. The last one to appear on the ceiling is minutely detailed and would seem to include every celestial body in the universe, and all of their magnitudes, motions, and constitutions.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY
dialogues.text: She stares intensely at this latest map of the universe, then finds the control that directs the lighted arrow along the ceiling. She wants to be as precise as possible. She takes her time, checking, rechecking. And then, with great precision, she stops the arrow at one particular point.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR JOEY
dialogues.text: He stares at the lighted arrow, knowing what it represents, trying, somehow, to absorb the wonder of it all, the staggering implications.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HOBBS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: May I help you? Joey whirls around, ready to fight. Mary turns.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: She's a no-nonsense woman in her mid-forties, briefcase in one hand, a cluster of books in the other. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Perhaps you'd like to offer an explanation... before I call security.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE , 133
dialogues.text: Joey takes a few steps toward her, stepping from the shadows. :

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Professor Hobbs? It's me... Joey Donizetti. Remember me? I'm the guy who always works on your car? She recognizes him, but still seems very uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: What are you doing in here, Joey? Joey seems to be at a momentary loss. How can he possibly explain it?

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY 134
dialogues.text: She's made a decision. She reaches for something in her pocket. Joey's anxious, unsure, maybe even afraid of what she might pull out.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S HAND 135
dialogues.text: She withdraws something from her pocket that's at first unrecognizable. It's a piece of flat metal, maybe copper, maybe gold. The edges are uneven, as if it's part of something larger that's been broken off.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY 136
dialogues.text: He stares at the object in Mary's hand.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR 137
dialogues.text: Could 4t be that she knows what it is? Her eyes narrow as she squints across the distance at it. And now, slowly, she begins to approach them.  138 139 140 45.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 138
dialogues.text: We still haven't been given a close view of the object in Mary's hand. The Professor stops advancing when she's come within touching distance. She stares at it » breathlessly. She raises her eyes to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (continuing) May I? Mary hands the piece of shiny metal to the Professor, who takes 1t and holds 1t and stares down at it as if it were a piece of the original Ten Commandments presented to Moses.

dialogues.speaker: OBJECT 139
dialogues.text: We see it clearly for the first time. Etched into the broken piece of @old-plated copper is a partial rendering of the human male and female figures, and a simple map-like drawing of our solar system, and out planet.

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR PROFESSOR 140
dialogues.text: She looks back at Mary, then turns to Joey. She seems to be having a profound religious experience.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: ; (continuing) Do you know what this 41s?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I'm not sure,

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: It was part of the Voyager satellite that we launched eight years ago. Then, almost instructionally, to Mary:

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (continuing) The complete package included a - phonograph record of scientific data... examples of sixty languages spoken on earth... microfilm photographs of the human race... music from all of our major cultures... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She trails off. A dead silence. Then, to Mary:

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR MARY
dialogues.text: She returns the Professor's probing stare, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where did you get 1t?

dialogues.speaker: FAVOR JOEY
dialogues.text: A slight smile appears on his face. He glances up at the giant chart of the cosmos.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Probably from somewhere in her neighborhood. The Professor stares at him. Joey points to the glowing arrow. -

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's pretty close.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE
dialogues.text: The by-now familiar silence encloses all of then. Professor Hobbs stares at the chart of the universe, then at Mary, then back down at the shiny metal in her hand. CAMERA MOVES into a CLOSE ANGLE of the object. ’ FADE OUT. END OF ACT Two 143

dialogues.speaker: ACT THREE
dialogues.text: FADE IN: oe EXT, PLANETARIUM - DAY eae! Lights glow from various buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey stands alone in the quiet on one side of a glass wall. On the opposite side are Mary and Professor Hobbs. Within the room are a number of computers of various size and description. Colored lights glow. Joey can't hear what's being said on the other side of the glass, but the essence of the scene is apparent. Copying an amazingly complex mathematical question from a small sheet of paper she holds, the Professor 1s writing it onto a blackboard. There appear to be more symbols than numbers. Even the majority of us, who will have no idea of what it is that she's writing, will understand that to comprehend such a question takes a real measure of brilliance. Mary merely watches, quietly watches. Finally finished, the Professor hands the stick of chalk to Mary, gives her some brief, last-minute instructions, then checks the time on her watch as she walks away, heading toward one of the computers. Joey stares at Mary, staring at the mass of symbols and numbers on the blackboard. The Professor sits down at a@ computer, the small sheet of paper beside her, ready to enter the same question. She raises her hands to begin typing, but suddenly stops. A SOUND has distracted her. She looks up. Joey looks. Mary is writing the answer to the question, writing steadily, in large and clear numbers and symbols on the blackboard. Professor Hobbs stares in speechless awe. Joey begins to grin. Mary continues to write. The Professor slowly stands. Joey's grin widens. Mary draws a line under her work, puts the chalk in the rack, turns toward the Professor -- without even the smallest trace of superiority in her expression. The Professor, staggered by this display of genius, feels suddenly weak in the kmees and slumps back onto her chair. Mary turns to look through the glass wall at Joey. He raises a thumb. :

dialogues.text: The Professor sits behind her desk. Joey and Mary sit opposite, All around the room are the signs and symbols of the Professor's world: heavenly globes, lush photographs of celestial bodies, a kinetic sculpture of the solar system. The atmosphere is scholarly; the mood portentous. By the Professor's attitude, it's apparent that even with all she's seen, and even though she wants to accept it fully, the pragmatic side of her won't quite allow total commitment.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Before I ... suggest ... a course *. - of action, I'd like to understand 7 a little more. For instance: your * method of space travel. *

dialogues.text: It's difficult to describe. *

dialogues.text: These... men. Your ... enemy. 7 You've implied that they're - determined,

dialogues.text: Yeah. Determined to kill.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. But‘you should know that in * another two days the alignment of * E our planets will change, making it * impossible to intercept the necessary * orbit. 7 * (pause; then) * (A, : None uf us will be able to return. *

dialogues.text: We'll live out our lives here. " “PROFESSOR You're prepared for that? 7

Then, Professor Do you have any idea of what it will be like for you here once your presence is acknowledged? can you imagine how difficult it will be for you? A pause. Then, simply: G. mane As I said, I have no choice. Stung by the reality, Joev looks away.

dialogues.text: May I ask one more question before we leave?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: How do you explain the fact that Physically, you appear identical to human beings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: ( Yes. A pause. Then,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cur TO:  155 weve Oy avut ‘EXT. OBSERVATORY BUILDING - pay * Joey and Mary stand on the stairs, waiting for the Professor to join them. For a moment, only the quiet.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. She turns to him, questioning him with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) For the last twenty-four hours, all I've been thinking about is two things: keeping us alive... and patting myself on the back for being the first man on earth to have found himself a real E.T. (pause; then) I never stopped to think about how you must be feeling... being alone. (pause; then) I'm sorry. 52. 155 A beat, and then Mary reaches out and touches him lightly on the face -- exactly in the same way he touched her, early this same morning. He takes her hand, then slowly raises it to his lips and kisses it very gently. She clearly doesn't know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do you... Kiss? A pause. She shakes her head, no. Then, like a secret admission:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I saw it on your television last night... for the first time. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Would you like to try? Still another pause, and then she nods, shyly. A beat, and then he places his hands lightly on the sides of her arms and slowly draws their bodies closer together. They kiss, as sweetly as kids on a first date. Mary keeps her eyes open. They part. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . first time, but much longer this time. Toward the end

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey nods. They kiss again, exactly the same as the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of it, perhaps instinctively, Mary lightly shuts her eyes. : : Ret eis ites eee Cee
